pullRequest.body:
Shows that all first-countable locally path-connected spaces are delta-generated (so in particular all normed spaces and convex subsets thereof are), and that delta-generated spaces are equivalently generated by the unit interval or standard simplices.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->
The main lemma used in this construction is unfortunately quite messy - it requires concatenating countably many paths leading up to a point, which is easy to see on paper but hard to formalise in lean. I've documented the argument in `LocPathConnectedSpace.eq_coinduced_paths` as good as I could, but eventually gave up on getting the `Path.sigmaConcat` construction into a good state and just marked it as private.

In principle, this should be close to all that's required to show that all simplicial complexes and CW-complexes are delta-generated; I just haven't done it yet because I'm not sure which file to best do it in.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
We've just had a look at this PR at the triage party; here are some comments.
1) This work looks great; I wonder if some of the private lemmas should in fact be public (specifically the one gluing infinitely many paths to form a path)
2) The large imports are nothing to worry about; this is basically a leaf file and if the logarithm is useful here, that's great.
3) Some of the proofs might need some rewriting but only in a minor way; it was a bit jarring to see a definition with a very long proof in the middle when the goal was still a type, but probably this doesn't actually matter.
4) I am always scared of `convert; [several more lines of proof]` because such proofs can be hard to maintain later on.

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

`+ sigmaConcat`
`+ sigmaConcatFun`
`+ sigmaConcatFun_eqOn`
`+ sigmaConcat_applyAt`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

In addition to incorporating some of the smaller suggestions, I have replaced my previous usage of `⌊Real.logb 2 x⌋₊` with `Nat.log 2 ⌊x⌋₊` following a suggestion by Yael on discord. This has cut down on the large imports significantly - while I still rely on analysis files for `tendsto_pow_atTop_nhds_zero_of_abs_lt_one` in `LocPathConnectedSpace.eq_coinduced_paths`, the lemmas regarding `Path.sigmaConcat` now depend only on `Mathlib.Data.Nat.Log`, and should thus be fine to move to e.g. `Mathlib.Topology.Connected.PathConnected`. I will try that in a few hours when I have time.

Can you use the notation?
```suggestion
  let n := ⌊- Real.logb 2 (σ t)⌋₊
```

Can you keep imports sorted?
```suggestion
import Mathlib.Analysis.LocallyConvex.WithSeminorms
import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Log.Base
import Mathlib.Topology.ContinuousMap.Interval
```

Here's a better way to present this definition
```suggestion
  let n := ⌊- Real.logb 2 (σ t)⌋₊
  refine if ht : t < 1 then γ n ⟨2 * (1 - σ t * 2 ^ (n : ℝ)), ?_, ?_⟩ else x
  · have ht' : 0 < σ t := by rw [lt_symm_comm]; simp [ht]
    have hn : (n : ℝ) ≤ _ := Nat.floor_le (a := - Real.logb 2 (σ t)) <|
      Left.nonneg_neg_iff.2 <| Real.logb_nonpos one_lt_two (σ t).2.1 (σ t).2.2
    have h : (2 : ℝ) ^ (n : ℝ) ≤ (σ t).1 ⁻¹ := by
      refine (Real.rpow_le_rpow_of_exponent_le one_le_two hn).trans ?_
      rw [Real.rpow_neg zero_le_two, Real.rpow_logb two_pos (by simp) (by simp [ht])]
    have h' : (σ t) * (2 : ℝ) ^ (n : ℝ) ≤ 1 := by
      refine (mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_left h (σ t).2.1).trans (mul_inv_cancel₀ ?_).le
      exact (coe_pos.2 ht').ne.symm
    linarith
  · have hn : _ < (n.succ : ℝ) := Nat.lt_succ_floor _
    have ht' : 0 < σ t := by rw [lt_symm_comm]; simp [ht]
    have h : (σ t).1⁻¹ ≤ 2 * 2 ^ (n : ℝ) := by
      rw [Real.rpow_natCast, ← pow_succ', ← Real.rpow_natCast]
      refine (Eq.le ?_).trans <| Real.rpow_le_rpow_of_exponent_le one_le_two hn.le
      rw [Real.rpow_neg zero_le_two, Real.rpow_logb two_pos (by simp) (by simp [ht])]
    suffices h : 1 ≤ (σ t) * (2 * (2 : ℝ) ^ (n : ℝ)) by rw [mul_left_comm] at h; linarith
    refine (mul_inv_cancel₀ ?_).symm.le.trans <| mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_left h (σ t).2.1
    exact (coe_pos.2 ht').ne.symm
```

Can you avoid using `1 / _`?
```suggestion
    (Set.Icc (σ ⟨2⁻¹  ^ n, by simp [inv_le_one₀, one_le_pow₀]⟩)
      (σ ⟨2⁻¹ ^ (n+1), by simp [inv_le_one₀, one_le_pow₀]⟩)) := fun t ht ↦ by
  simp only [Set.mem_Icc, ← Subtype.coe_le_coe, coe_symm_eq] at ht
```
This looks like a great definition. Why keep it private? I think it should live in an earlier file too (possibly a new file)

It feels a bit weird to ask for an antitone basis when in fact an *eventually* antitone basis is enough. I want to say something like "the paths uniformly converge towards the point", but I'm not sure how to say that without the data of a uniformity

pullRequest.title: feat(Topology/Compactness): first-countable locally path-connected spaces are delta-generated

nodes.body:
We've just had a look at this PR at the triage party; here are some comments.
1) This work looks great; I wonder if some of the private lemmas should in fact be public (specifically the one gluing infinitely many paths to form a path)
2) The large imports are nothing to worry about; this is basically a leaf file and if the logarithm is useful here, that's great.
3) Some of the proofs might need some rewriting but only in a minor way; it was a bit jarring to see a definition with a very long proof in the middle when the goal was still a type, but probably this doesn't actually matter.
4) I am always scared of `convert; [several more lines of proof]` because such proofs can be hard to maintain later on.

### PR summary [6a7bac87ad](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20248/commits/6a7bac87ad0df0a9d901e3178ab4ecdf526cd1b4)

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

In addition to incorporating some of the smaller suggestions, I have replaced my previous usage of `⌊Real.logb 2 x⌋₊` with `Nat.log 2 ⌊x⌋₊` following a suggestion by Yael on discord. This has cut down on the large imports significantly - while I still rely on analysis files for `tendsto_pow_atTop_nhds_zero_of_abs_lt_one` in `LocPathConnectedSpace.eq_coinduced_paths`, the lemmas regarding `Path.sigmaConcat` now depend only on `Mathlib.Data.Nat.Log`, and should thus be fine to move to e.g. `Mathlib.Topology.Connected.PathConnected`. I will try that in a few hours when I have time.
